isis.stitle: Recall 99305 - AmTran RE™ Rear Emergency Exit Window

recall.subject: AmTran RE™ Rear Emergency Exit Window

defect.para: This Recall applies to AmTran RE buses, with the standard 74-inch headroom, built from March 1, 1998 through April 21, 1999.

American Transportation Corporation (AmTran) has determined that certain AmTran RE™ buses fail to conform to Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 217, "Bus Window Retention and Release." This defect involves the rear emergency exit window on buses with the standard 74 inch headroom only.

Some rear emergency exit windows in AmTran RE buses, with 74 inch headroom, do not meet the requirement of 41 centimeter (16.1 inches) vertical opening as specified in FMVSS 217. The window is hinged at the top, and when fully opened, the frame that surrounds the glass surface reduces the opening to 38.8 centimeters (15.3 inches) or 2.2 centimeters (0.9 inch) less than the required height.
Owners are being notified of this recall and have been directed to contact an AmTran dealer to make arrangements for inspection and remedy of the defect.

note.para: TPI has issued a recall # 99-001 (NHTSA # 99E-030) involving some of the same vehicles for other defects with the same window. This recall may supersede TPI's recall # 99-001. Therefore if the unit involved in this recall does not have the correct hinge style as displayed in example "B" or "C", and has the hinge style as shown in example "A" (which has the non-compliant opening), the repair for this recall will negate the need for TPI's recall.
When the "AUTHORIZATION FOR RECALL SERVICE" card is returned with box #8 (Replacement Required) checked, we will notify TPI that the same unit on their recall will be repaired by this recall.

svcproc.title: INSPECTION
svcproc.para: Inspection of this defect requires looking at the hinge construction of the emergency rear exit window in the unit involved and comparing it to the photos below.

Example "A" below shows the hinge construction used on the windows that are non- compliant. If the emergency exit window hinge construction on the bus being inspected matches example "A", return the "AUTHORIZATION FOR RECALL SERVICE" card making sure that box #8 (Replacement Required) is checked. Make sure that your correct shipping address (i.e., not a P.O. Box number) is on the card. The kit with instructions will be shipped directly to the facility making the repair.

Example "B" and "C" below show the hinge construction used on the windows that are compliant. If the emergency exit window hinge construction on the bus being inspected matches example "B" or "C", return the "AUTHORIZATION FOR RECALL SERVICE" card making sure that box #1 (Inspected - No corrections necessary) is checked and apply the "Campaign Identification Label" (instructions below).

svcproc.title: REPAIR PROCEDURE
svcproc.para: The repair for this defect will require removing the current window assembly and replacing it with a new window assembly. Material for the new window should be available after December 28, 1999.

laborinfo.para: Time below is the allowable time for each procedure. Replacement procedure requires two individuals, and will take approximately 35 minutes to perform the repair procedure.

label.para: Each vehicle corrected and/or inspected in accordance with Campaign 99305 will require a CTS-1075 Campaign Identification Label. Print the number " 99305" under the words "Campaign No." Print the " Serial No." after the word "VIN". Print the Service Location Code # " NUMBER" under the words "Service Location Code #" if you are a dealer or have been assigned a code. Attach the completed CTS-1075 label on a clean surface next to the vehicle identification number (VIN) plate. Apply clear overlay over the label for protection.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner's vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
